questions.text:
Which of the following is the correct sequence of auditory pathway?
a) Superior Olivary nucleus
b) Inferior colliculus
c) Lateral Lemniscus
d) Spiral ganglion
e) Cochlear nucleus
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sequence of the Auditory pathway:

Spiral ganglion of 8th nerve in Modiolus of Cochlea → Cochlear division of 8th nerve → Cochlear nucleus → Superior Olivary Complex → Nucleus of Lateral Lemniscus → Inferior Colliculus → Medial Geniculate Body → Auditory Cortex.

questions.text: Which nerve is located anterior to Bill's bar in the internal auditory meatus?
questions.solution:
• Bill's bar is a vertical bony septum that divides the superior compartment of the internal acoustic meatus into anterior and posterior compartments.
  • Anterior to Bill's bar is the facial nerve (CN VII), and the superior vestibular nerve is posterior to it.
  • Bill's island is a thin plate of bone left on the sigmoid sinus when it is to be retracted during surgery. It should be differentiated from Bill's bar.

questions.text: A steel factory worker is suffering from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Induced Hearing Loss causes damage to hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells.
  • Outer hair cells are vulnerable to sounds and drugs, while the inner hair cells are more resistant.
  • The basal region of the organ of Corti (closest to the oval window) processes high-frequency sounds and is the first area to suffer OHC injury from noise exposure.

The damage caused by noise trauma depends on several factors:

  • Frequency of noise: A frequency of 2000-3000 Hz causes more damage than lower or higher frequencies.
  • Intensity and duration of noise: As the intensity increases, the permissible time for exposure is reduced.
  • Continuous vs interrupted noise: Continuous noise is more harmful.
  • Susceptibility of the individual: The degree of TTS and PTS varies in different individuals.
  • Pre-existing ear disease.

questions.text: Mutations in which gap junction protein gene account for the highest percentage of non-syndromic congenital sensorineural hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mutations in the Connexin 26 gap junction protein gene account for the highest Non-Syndromic SNHL.

Non-Syndromic SNHL:

  • SNHL in a child or young adult without a known acquired cause and any associated unusual physical features is called non-syndromic deafness.
  • Most non-syndromic forms of deafness are monogenic and rare, except one form caused by inheritance of a homozygous autosomal recessive mutant gene for the gap junction protein Connexin 26.
  • The GJB2 gene, which encodes connexin 26, is the most frequently mutated gap junction protein associated with non-syndromic congenital sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), accounting for approximately 50% of autosomal recessive and 20-50% overall of congenital cases.
  • While mutations in connexin 30 (GJB6)(Option B ruled out) also contribute to hearing loss, they are far less common and often occur alongside GJB2 mutations (digenic inheritance).
  • Mutations affecting connexin 43 (GJA1)(Option A ruled out) and connexin 32 (GJB1)(Option C ruled out) can be involved in hearing defects, but these are rare and not major contributors compared to connexin 26

questions.text: The most common viral infection to cause unilateral Sensorineural Hearing loss is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Mumps is well-known to cause sudden, unilateral SNHL, especially after parotitis, occurring within 4-5 days of symptom onset.
  • Before widespread vaccination, mumps was regarded as the most common cause of acquired unilateral hearing loss in children.
  • The incidence varies (from ~0.005% to 0.3%) depending on regional data and vaccination coverage, but it consistently tops the list among viral causes.

Explanation of other options:

Rubella (Option A): Typically leads to bilateral congenital hearing loss, not an acute unilateral onset.

Herpes simplex (Option C: Can cause unilateral SNHL, but incidence is less frequent and often associated with congenital forms or reactivation syndromes.

Epstein-Barr virus (Option D): Reports show occasional hearing loss in infectious mononucleosis, but it's significantly less common than mumps-related SNHL

questions.text: One of the following is not a criterion to label a hearing loss as Sudden SNHL
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Bilateral hearing loss is not the criterion to label a hearing loss as sudden SNHL.

Sudden SNHL:

Definition:

  • It is defined as sudden hearing loss of a minimum of 30dB(Option A ruled out).
  • It should be visible in at least 3 continuous frequencies in PTA(Option B ruled out).
  • It should have happened within 3 days. (Option C ruled out).
  • It's unilateral. And has an Unknown aetiology.

Hypothesis:

  • Inflammatory cochleitis.
  • Viral cochleitis.
  • Autoimmune disease.
  • Vascular cause.

Treatment :

DOC-oral steroids.

Other treatments:

  • Transtympanic injection of dexamethasone (using MICROWICK).
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy.
  • Betahistine (It is a labyrinthine vasodilator).
  • Antiviral drugs.

questions.text: A patient has developed high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. The cause of hearing loss is found to be due to the pathology of the basilar membrane. Which structure lies closest to the site of pathology?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • High-frequency sensorineural hearing loss due to basilar membrane pathology affects the basal turn of the cochlea, which lies closest to the oval window, the entry point for sound energy into the inner ear via the stapes.
  • Basal turn - senses High Frequency sounds (8000 Hz)
  • Apex turns - senses Low Frequency sounds (250 Hz)
  • Basal turn of the Cochlea - close to the oval window.

questions.text: A Feature of Scheibe dysplasia is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scheibe dysplasia:

  • Most common inner ear anomaly.
  • Dysplasia of the cochlea and saccule; hence also called cochleosaccular dysplasia. (Pars Inferior)
  • Bony labyrinths are normal. (Option B ruled out).
  • The superior part of the membranous labyrinth(utricle and semicircular ducts) is normal. (Pars Superior)(Option A ruled out).
  • 1.5 turns in the cochlea is seen in Mondini Deformity(Option D ruled out).

questions.text: A patient presents with a long-standing complaint of vertigo on hearing loud sounds and hearing loss, which is conductive on audiometry, with deranged findings of Vestibular evoked myogenic potential testing. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above are the characteristic features of the SSC Dehiscence syndrome with long-standing vertigo and conductive hearing loss.

Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence Syndrome:

  • Congenital
  • Traumatic or head injury.

Clinical picture:

This patient will have CHL due to the leakage of sound energy from this dehiscence. This is called the 3rd window phenomenon.

  • This patient will complain of vertigo on hearing loud sounds. This phenomenon is called Tullio's phenomenon.
  • Vertigo on blowing of nose.
  • False positive fistula sign (Heinnebert sign)

Investigations-

  • VEMP
  • HRCT temporal bone.
  • PTA helps in the differentiation of CHL and

Treatment-

surgical closure (graft to close dehiscence).

Explanation of other options:

BPPV(Option A): Typically presents with brief, positional vertigo. It does not cause conductive hearing loss or VEMP changes.

Menière's disease(Option B): Causes episodic vertigo with sensorineural, not conductive, hearing loss. VEMP may be abnormal, but presentation doesn't involve sound-induced vertigo.

Vestibular schwannoma(Option D): Typically produces sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and imbalance, not sound-induced vertigo or conductive hearing loss.

questions.text: Heinnebert sign can be seen in all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Heinebert's sign is the absence of the stapedial reflex (also called the acoustic reflex).
  • It is observed by looking for the contraction of the stapedius muscle in response to a loud sound.
  • The absence of this reflex suggests damage to the stapedial reflex arc, which involves the cochlea, vestibular nerve, facial nerve, and stapedius muscle.
  • In SSC dehiscence syndrome, the above are not damaged, and the stapedial reflex is preserved, and Hennebert's sign is not seen.
  • All other diseases above are characterised by damage to any of the given structures and lead to absent stapedial reflex and presence of Hennebert's sign. (Other options ruled out).

questions.text: The pathway of spread of infection to the cochlea in meningitis is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The main pathway of spread of infection to the cochlea in meningitis is through the Cochlear aqueduct.
  • Venous drainage of the labyrinth is through three veins, namely the internal auditory vein, the vein of cochlear aqueduct and the vein of vestibular aqueduct, which ultimately drain into the inferior petrosal sinus and lateral venous sinus.
  • Bacterial infections reach the labyrinth through the middle ear (tympanogenic) or CSF (meningogenic).
  • Sensorineural hearing loss following meningitis is a well-known clinical entity. Bacteria can invade the labyrinth along nerves, vessels, the cochlear aqueduct or the endolymphatic sac. The membranous labyrinth is destroyed.

Explanation of other Options:

Endolymphatic sac(Option B): Regulates endolymph pressure and has no direct link to the meninges.

Vestibular aqueduct(Option C): Contains endolymphatic duct but is not the primary route of infection.

Ductus reuniens(Option D): Connects the cochlear duct to the saccule (endolymph system) and is not connected to the meninges.

questions.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential(VEMP) tests, which nerve
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • VEMP tests the Inferior vestibular division of the 8th nerve.

VEMP (Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential):

  • In this test, we stimulate the Saccule with a loud sound, and we record the electrical activity of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.
  • VEMP is a test to detect the function of
    • Saccule
    • Inferior vestibular division of the 8th
  • This nerve supplies to Saccule.

Types of VEMP:

  • cVEMP (cervical Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential) evaluates the function of the saccule and the inferior portion of the vestibular nerve (inferior vestibular nerve) by measuring responses from the sternocleidomastoid muscle
  • This is a test to study the function of otolith organs-the saccule and utricle. Normally, their function is linear acceleration. They can also be stimulated by the loud sound of air or bone conduction. Even tapping the head can stimulate them.
  • Myogenic potentials can be picked up from either the sternocleidomastoid (cervical) muscle or ocular muscle (inferior oblique or superior rectus) and have respectively been called cVEMP and oVEMP.
  • Since the saccule is supplied by the inferior division of the nerve and the utricle by the superior division, study of VEMP in neuroma can help us to find its origin from the superior or inferior division.

Reflex arc is:

  • From saccule-inferior vestibular-vestibular nuclei-ipsilateral vestibular spinal tract-spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)-sternocleidomastoid
  • From utricle-superior vestibular nerve-vestibular nuclei-medial longitudinal fasciculus-oculomotor (CNIII) nerve-inferior oblique muscle
  • Air-conducted sounds primarily activate the saccule, while bone-conducted sounds activate both the saccule and the utricle.

Uses of VEMP-

  • Acoustic neuroma.
  • Superior semicircular canal dehiscence.
  • Meniere's disease.

questions.text: Auditory brainstem implant electrode in a case of Neurofibroma type 2 is placed in which location?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This implant is designed to stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem directly by placing the implant in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle.
  • Such an implant is needed when CN VIII has been severed in the surgery of a vestibular schwannoma. In these cases, cochlear implants are obviously of no use.
  • In unilateral acoustic neuroma, ABI is not necessary as hearing is possible from the contralateral side, but in bilateral acoustic neuromas, as in NF2, rehabilitation is required by ABI.
